subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... While your progressive transcription of _Alice_ is a really admirable piece of work, you do explicitly violate Read s rule about writing R, as well as the
messageBody:
peter_r_guinness scripsit:

> If you want to see what an example of Australian junior quickscript,
> you can look chapter 12 of my tutorials:
> http://members.optusnet.com.au/~malt99/project_quickscript_website/index.html

While your progressive transcription of _Alice_ is a really admirable
piece of work, you do explicitly violate Read's rule about writing R,
as well as the rule using It instead of Eat for "-y". That makes it
of limited utility for rhotic speakers, who are the great majority of
native speakers worldwide.

> The majority of Australians have the same general
> accent, due to the fact that it is a only a couple of hundred years
> old, it is very urbanised (basically Australia is just five cities -
> I think it has some claim to being the worlds most urbanised
> country) where most TV broadcasts and some radio are Australia wide.

Sidebar: TV is nationwide for the most part in the U.S. too, yet two
new dialects (Inland North and Inland South) have differentiated in the
past 50 years, mostly under the radar. Indeed, the Inland North dialect
developed in the cities (among whites; African American Vernacular English
speakers are not affected) and is only now spreading to rural areas.
So the fact that the Australian accent is basically nationwide requires
some other kind of explanation.

> The broad drawn-out country Australian accent where people say day
> as die is not really representative of the majority.

True.

--
John Cowan http://ccil.org/~cowan cowan@...
Lope de Vega: "It wonders me I can speak at all. Some caitiff rogue did
rudely yerk me on the knob, wherefrom my wits still wander."
An Englishman: "Ay, a filchman to the nab betimes 'll leave a man
crank for a spell." --Harry Turtledove, Ruled Britannia
